moves.1. e4: He uses a popular opening: King's Pawn game.
moves.2. Bc4: He opens up his bishop, ignoring the classic theory: 'Knights before bishops'.
moves.2... a6: I push up my pawn, preparing to threaten his bishop with my b-pawn. I probably should have been getting my pieces out, but, like usual, I was trying something.
moves.3. a4: I still can push up my pawn, the result would would be a swapping of pawns.: b5 4. Bd3 bxa4 5. Rxa4.
moves.4. Qf3: He opens up his queen surprisingly early, looking for 'Scholar's mate', a checkmate using the bishop to protect the queen as she takes the f-pawn. 'Scholar's mate' is one that beginners fall for. I will not.
moves.4... Nf6: I open up my knight, at the same time preventing the queen from reaching my pawn.
moves.5. h3: This doesn't do anything, he should be getting his pieces out.
moves.5... Bc5: I open my bishop, and am now in a position to castle.
moves.6... Bd4: I threaten his knight with my bishop.
moves.7. Nd5: He moves forward, threatening my knight.
moves.7... d6: I ignore the threat and prepare: Be6.
moves.10. a5: Yet again, he threatens my bishop, and yet again…
moves.11. b5: He now threatens my knight, and I'm not liking my position so much.
moves.11... axb5: I take his pawn with my own.
moves.12. Bxb5: And he takes mine with his bishop, he is still threatening my knight.
moves.12... Bb6: I push up my bishop, preparing to take the free pawn. If you ask why I would sacrifice my bishop, look again at the position, at both my and my opponents rooks.
moves.13. Bxc6+: He takes my knight, checking the king.
moves.13... bxc6: I take his bishop with my pawn.
moves.14. Nxf6+: He takes my bishop with his knight, checking me and I obviously…
moves.15. Ne2: He is now in a castling position.
moves.15... Rg8: I must have forgot about the free pawn…
moves.16... Bxa5: I take the free pawn with my bishop.
moves.17... Bb7: I see something. A could pin the pawn to his queen and persuade his pawn to take one of my pieces, which would give me the queen, but how do i get to this position? I see my pawn on f6: My bait, And my pawn on c6, my barricade. Now I'm thinking further. The rook and bishop connect and collide on the g2 square.
moves.18. Rfd1: He uses his rook to protect the pawn.
moves.18... c5:
I go for it, trying out my plan. ^^
                                          00
                                           V
                                           -
moves.19... Qd7: I push my queen out in case he decides to take my pawn with his queen.
moves.20. g4: No matter, he is pinned to his king with my rook. But I don't see that, so I try to get rid of the pawn.
moves.20... h5: I try to get him out of the way, then I realize his g-pawn can't take me, and it can't take my pawn when I move it to f5..
moves.21. d3: This move doesn't do anything, thats what i needed, a move that doesn't threat any of my pieces or get in the way of my plan.
moves.21... f5: He can take with his pawn or his queen, or he can just totally ignore it, either way, I get at least a pawn.
moves.22. exf5: A very bad move, but my plan worked!
moves.22... Bxf3:
I take his queen, and he resigns! :D
Until I captured his pawn in move 15, I was worried, really worried. But, what a game! Thank you for reading my Sixth Annotated Blitz game!
